Without individual health/lifestyle data, population averages are the best reference. Confidence is moderate (0.85) because: 1) ~68% of U.S. male deaths occur within ±15 years of life expectancy (SD ≈15 years), so ±20 years covers >80% of cases; 2) avoiding early mortality reduces extreme outliers.

The life expectancy for an American male who has lived to age 27 is approximately 78 years, based on U.S. Social Security Administration period life tables (2019), which indicate about 51 additional years of life expectancy at age 27 (27 + 51 = 78). However, individual lifespans vary significantly due to health, lifestyle, genetics, and socioeconomic factors. The standard deviation for age at death in this demographic is roughly 15 years, making precise prediction highly uncertain. The probability of the true age falling within ±1 year of 78 is low, as the distribution of lifespans is spread widely.

Statistical analysis shows >99.99% of 77-year-old American females die by 108 (probability of survival to 108 is ~0.00015, calculated via life table extrapolation: 3.8% survive to 100, and with a conservative 50% annual mortality rate beyond 100, survival to 108 is 0.038 × (0.5)^8 ≈ 0.00015). Thus, |88 - true age| ≤ 20 holds with near certainty.
